text.p: Microsoft Corp, moving to make access to the Internet more like watching television, said on Wednesday it proposed a set of so-called "push" software technologies to the World Wide Web's standard-setting body.
The technology would let Internet news organizations and entertainment sites broadcast their programs to specific computer users interested in getting them.
The company also said America Online Inc, the nation's biggest online service, has agreed to use CDF to broadcast Internet programs to its 8 million subscribers.
PointCast Inc, a closely held broadcasters of news through the Internet, also said it agreed to use Microsoft's push software standards.
Microsoft said the technology, called channel definition format, will be a part of the next version of its Internet Explorer browser, the program that lets computer users search the Internet.
Microsoft's set of proposed standards would compete against technologies from several startups such as Marimba Inc.
Microsoft has a history of proposing its own set of software standards to boost its products in new markets.
